results.title: Sign Up for the Science Times Newsletter
results.abstract: Every week, we’ll bring you stories that capture the wonders of the human body, nature and the cosmos.

results.title: ‘Red Flags’ on Climate: U.S. Methane Emissions Keep Climbing
results.abstract: Satellite data shows the U.S. releasing more and more of the potent greenhouse gas into the atmosphere, researchers said, despite pledges to cut back.

multimedia.caption: The concentration of methane in the atmosphere is now more than two-and-a-half times greater than preindustrial levels.
The concentration of methane in the atmosphere is now more than two-and-a-half times greater than preindustrial levels.
The concentration of methane in the atmosphere is now more than two-and-a-half times greater than preindustrial levels.

results.title: Tyson Faces Lawsuit Over Labeling of ‘Climate-Smart’ Beef
results.abstract: An environmental group said the company, a major food producer, was misleading shoppers with its claims about eco-friendly practices.

multimedia.caption: Brazen Beef, a new Tyson Foods brand with packaging that uses the language “climate friendly.”
Brazen Beef, a new Tyson Foods brand with packaging that uses the language “climate friendly.”
Brazen Beef, a new Tyson Foods brand with packaging that uses the language “climate friendly.”

results.title: Floods Wreak Havoc Across Four Continents
results.abstract: Flooding events around the world share a common factor of an atmosphere made warmer by climate change. What can be done to help citizens prepare?
results.byline: By Austyn Gaffney and Somini Sengupta

multimedia.caption: The swollen Elbe river in Dresden, Germany, on Tuesday.
The swollen Elbe river in Dresden, Germany, on Tuesday.
The swollen Elbe river in Dresden, Germany, on Tuesday.

results.title: Bulletproofing America’s Classrooms
results.abstract: Ballistic armor companies are marketing protective products designed for the military to parents and schools. Some people see the items as unsettling but prudent; others find them infuriating.
results.byline: By Emily Baumgaertner and Alex Kalman

results.title: What R.F.K. Jr.’s Alliance With Trump Could Mean for Public Health
results.abstract: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who has long voiced doubts about vaccine safety, has hopes of influencing federal health policy. Could he finally get the chance?

multimedia.caption: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. speaking at a rally in May. Donald Trump has said that he “probably would” appoint Mr. Kennedy to a role in his administration.
multimedia.copyright: Rachel Woolf for The New York Times

results.title: How Colorado Cowboys and Conservationists Joined Forces to Stop Drilling
results.abstract: The members of a self-described ragtag group had little in common, but their campaign could serve as model for future environmental efforts.
results.byline: By Zoë Rom and Eli Imadali

multimedia.copyright: Eli Imadali for The New York Times
Eli Imadali for The New York Times
Eli Imadali for The New York Times

results.title: Plastic Waste and Toxic Sludge: A Sweep of a Messy Beat
results.abstract: The Climate reporter Hiroko Tabuchi is interested in all the things we take for granted about our environment.

multimedia.caption: In 2019, the reporter Hiroko Tabuchi traveled to Texas to report on large amounts of methane escaping from oil and gas sites.
multimedia.copyright: Jonah M. Kessel/The New York Times

results.title: Deep Links Between Alcohol and Cancer Are Described in New Report
results.abstract: Scientists continue to rethink the idea that moderate drinking offers health benefits.

multimedia.caption: Excessive alcohol consumption increases the risk of six different types of cancer, but consumers are generally unaware.
multimedia.copyright: Karsten Moran for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Excessive alcohol consumption increases the risk of six different types of cancer, but consumers are generally unaware.

results.title: Flooding in Europe Is a ‘Clear Reminder’ of the Threat of Extreme Weather
results.abstract: Climate change is influencing extreme weather events like the flooding across six countries that has led to mass evacuations of cities as the waters continue to rise.

multimedia.caption: Rescue workers evacuating flooded areas in Ostrava, Czech Republic, on Monday.
Rescue workers evacuating flooded areas in Ostrava, Czech Republic, on Monday.
Rescue workers evacuating flooded areas in Ostrava, Czech Republic, on Monday.

results.title: A Supermoon and Lunar Eclipse Will Light Up and Darken Tuesday’s Night Sky
results.abstract: Earth’s shadow will partially cover one of the biggest and brightest full moons this year.

multimedia.caption: A partial lunar eclipse over Sana, Yemen, last October.
A partial lunar eclipse over Sana, Yemen, last October.
A partial lunar eclipse over Sana, Yemen, last October.

results.title: How Does Pregnancy Change the Brain? Clues Are Emerging.
results.abstract: As hormones surge, some brain areas shrink in what scientists say may be a fine-tuning that helps mothers bond with and care for their babies.

multimedia.caption: Brain scans of a woman during pregnancy showed that some areas shrink, possibly becoming more specialized, while neurological fibers appear to show temporarily improved communication.
Brain scans of a woman during pregnancy showed that some areas shrink, possibly becoming more specialized, while neurological fibers appear to show temporarily improved communication.
Brain scans of a woman during pregnancy showed that some areas shrink, possibly becoming more specialized, while neurological fibers appear to show temporarily improved communication.

results.title: First Day of a ‘New Life’ for a Boy With Sickle Cell
results.abstract: Kendric Cromer, 12, is among the first patients to be treated with gene therapy just approved by the F.D.A. that many other patients face obstacles to receiving.
results.byline: By Gina Kolata and Kenny Holston

multimedia.caption: Kendric Cromer undergoing infusion gene therapy for his sickle cell disease at Children’s National Hospital in Washington last week.
Kendric Cromer undergoing infusion gene therapy for his sickle cell disease at Children’s National Hospital in Washington last week.
Kendric Cromer undergoing infusion gene therapy for his sickle cell disease at Children’s National Hospital in Washington last week.

results.title: Titan Submersible Company Neglected Safety Concerns, Ex-Employees Say
results.abstract: Former employees of the company, OceanGate, said they worried about its practices long before a fatal implosion that killed five people. A Coast Guard hearing resumes on Tuesday.
results.byline: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and William J. Broad

multimedia.caption: The Titan submersible in an undated photo at the beginning of a dive.
The Titan submersible in an undated photo at the beginning of a dive.
The Titan submersible in an undated photo at the beginning of a dive.

results.title: Dr. George Berci, Whose Innovations Changed Surgery, Dies at 103
results.abstract: He conceived many of the techniques and tools that have revolutionized minimally invasive operations and procedures.

multimedia.caption: Dr. George Berci in 2018 at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, where he was the senior director of minimally invasive surgery until earlier this summer.
Dr. George Berci in 2018 at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, where he was the senior director of minimally invasive surgery until earlier this summer.
Dr. George Berci in 2018 at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, where he was the senior director of minimally invasive surgery until earlier this summer.

results.title: Three Medical Practices That Older Patients Should Question
results.abstract: Some treatments and procedures become routine despite lacking strong evidence to show that they’re beneficial. Recent studies have called a few into question.

results.title: Missouri Bird Flu Case Raises Prospect of Human Transmission
results.abstract: A close contact of someone with bird flu became ill on the same day, the C.D.C. reported. But the second person was not tested, and the cause of the illness is unknown.
results.byline: By Apoorva Mandavilli and Emily Anthes
org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

multimedia.caption: An electron microscope image of an avian influenza H5N1 virion.
multimedia.copyright: Jackie Katz Cynthia Goldsmith/C.D.C., via Associated Press

results.title: W.H.O. Authorizes Mpox Vaccine, Clearing Way for Use in Africa
results.abstract: The decision is a crucial step in getting shots to the Democratic Republic of Congo, the center of the outbreak.

multimedia.caption: The Jynneos vaccine, made by Bavarian Nordic, has been approved in Europe as well as the United States and other high-income countries since a global mpox outbreak in 2022.
The Jynneos vaccine, made by Bavarian Nordic, has been approved in Europe as well as the United States and other high-income countries since a global mpox outbreak in 2022.

results.title: Starliner Astronauts Say What They’ll Miss During Extended Stay in Space
results.abstract: Suni Williams and Butch Wilmore of NASA spoke from the International Space Station for the first time since their Boeing orbital transport returned to Earth uncrewed.
results.byline: By Katrina Miller and Kenneth Chang

multimedia.caption: The NASA astronauts Suni Williams and Butch Wilmore talked to the news media from the International Space Station on Friday.
The NASA astronauts Suni Williams and Butch Wilmore talked to the news media from the International Space Station on Friday.
The NASA astronauts Suni Williams and Butch Wilmore talked to the news media from the International Space Station on Friday.

results.title: Boar’s Head Shuts Down Virginia Plant Tied to Listeria Deaths
results.abstract: The company said that the site would close indefinitely and that it would permanently stop making liverwurst. Union officials said the plant’s 500 workers would be given severance and offered relocation.
results.byline: By Christina Jewett and Teddy Rosenbluth

multimedia.caption: Boar’s Head announced that it would close the plant in Jarratt, Va., indefinitely.
Boar’s Head announced that it would close the plant in Jarratt, Va., indefinitely.
Boar’s Head announced that it would close the plant in Jarratt, Va., indefinitely.

results.title: The Big City Is Vibrant. Birds There Might Be Getting Less So.
results.abstract: Recent studies show that certain feather pigments can help neutralize toxic pollution. It means darker, duller birds could have a survival advantage.

multimedia.caption: Great tits, a common species in Europe, that were part of a study on urban birds in Malmo, Sweden.
Great tits, a common species in Europe, that were part of a study on urban birds in Malmo, Sweden.
Great tits, a common species in Europe, that were part of a study on urban birds in Malmo, Sweden.

results.title: A New Mini-Moon Is Being Captured by Planet Earth
results.abstract: It’s just a little guy, and not everyone agrees that it’s actually a mini-moon.

results.title: This Chatbot Pulls People Away From Conspiracy Theories
results.abstract: In a new study, many people doubted or abandoned false beliefs after a short conversation with the DebunkBot.

multimedia.caption: Buzz Aldrin, left, and Neil Armstrong practiced during a rehearsal for the moon landing in April 1969. One conspiracy theory holds that the event was staged.
Buzz Aldrin, left, and Neil Armstrong practiced during a rehearsal for the moon landing in April 1969. One conspiracy theory holds that the event was staged.
Buzz Aldrin, left, and Neil Armstrong practiced during a rehearsal for the moon landing in April 1969. One conspiracy theory holds that the event was staged.

results.title: Elevated Lead Levels Found in One-Third of Cinnamon Samples
results.abstract: Consumer Reports found lead in a variety of products, at a time when federal regulators are seeking authority from Congress to combat the problem of heavy metals in foods.
org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

multimedia.caption: Cinnamon products identified by the Food and Drug Administration in March as having high levels of lead.
Cinnamon products identified by the Food and Drug Administration in March as having high levels of lead.
